question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute
\[\cos^3 \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{8 \pi}{7}.\]
inference:
Let $x = \frac{2 \pi}{7}$. Then the sum is
$$ S = \cos^3 x + \cos^3 2x + \cos^3 4x. $$
We use the identity
$$ \cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta. $$
Thus
$$ \cos^3 \theta = \frac{\cos 3 \theta + 3 \cos \theta}{4}. $$
Then
\begin{align*} S &= \frac{\cos 3x + 3 \cos x}{4} + \frac{\cos 6x + 3 \cos 2x}{4} + \frac{\cos 12x + 3 \cos 4x}{4} \\ &= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x + 3 \cos x + 3 \cos 2x + 3 \cos 4x) \\ &= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x) + \frac{3}{4} (\cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x) \end{align*} 
We use the sum-to-product formulas to find the cosine sums.
\begin{align*} \cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x &= \frac{\sin \frac{7x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} \cos \frac{3x}{2} \\ \cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x &= \frac{\sin \frac{9x}{2}}{\sin \frac{3x}{2}} \cos \frac{9x}{2} \end{align*} 
Using $x = \frac{2 \pi}{7}$, we have
$$ \cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x = \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} = \frac{\sin \frac{7 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}}{\sin \frac{\frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}} \cos \frac{3 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{7 \pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{\pi}{7}} \cos \frac{3 \pi}{7} = 0 $$
And we also have
$$ \cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x = \frac{\sin \frac{9 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}}{\sin \frac{3 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}} \cos \frac{9 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{9 \pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{7}} \cos \frac{9 \pi}{7} = 0 $$
So $S = \frac{1}{4} (0) + \frac{3}{4} (0) = 0$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$
ground_truth:
The triple angle formula states that $\cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta.$  Then
\[\cos^3 \theta = \frac{1}{4} \cos 3 \theta + \frac{3}{4} \cos \theta.\]Hence,
\begin{align*}
\cos^3 \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{8 \pi}{7} &= \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} \right) + \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \right) + \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{24 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \left( \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{24 \pi}{7} \right) + \frac{3}{4} \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \left( \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \right) + \frac{3}{4} \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7}.
\end{align*}Consider the sum
\[S = \operatorname{cis} 0 + \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7}.\]Then
\begin{align*}
S \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} &= \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} 2 \pi \\
&= \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} 0 \\
&= S,
\end{align*}so $S \left( 1 - \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} \right) = 0.$  Hence, $S = 0.$

Taking the real part of $S$ gives us
\[\cos 0 + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{10 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} = 0.\]Then
\[1 + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} = 0,\]so
\[\cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} = \boxed{-\frac{1}{2}}.\]

question:
Let $x = \frac{2 \pi}{7}$. Then the sum is
$$ S = \cos^3 x + \cos^3 2x + \cos^3 4x. $$
We use the identity
$$ \cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta. $$
Thus
$$ \cos^3 \theta = \frac{\cos 3 \theta + 3 \cos \theta}{4}. $$
Then
\begin{align*} S &= \frac{\cos 3x + 3 \cos x}{4} + \frac{\cos 6x + 3 \cos 2x}{4} + \frac{\cos 12x + 3 \cos 4x}{4} \\ &= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x + 3 \cos x + 3 \cos 2x + 3 \cos 4x) \\ &= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x) + \frac{3}{4} (\cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x) \end{align*} 
We use the sum-to-product formulas to find the cosine sums.
\begin{align*} \cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x &= \frac{\sin \frac{7x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} \cos \frac{3x}{2} \\ \cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x &= \frac{\sin \frac{9x}{2}}{\sin \frac{3x}{2}} \cos \frac{9x}{2} \end{align*} 
Using $x = \frac{2 \pi}{7}$, we have
$$ \cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x = \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} = \frac{\sin \frac{7 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}}{\sin \frac{\frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}} \cos \frac{3 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{7 \pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{\pi}{7}} \cos \frac{3 \pi}{7} = 0 $$
And we also have
$$ \cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x = \frac{\sin \frac{9 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}}{\sin \frac{3 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2}} \cos \frac{9 \times \frac{2 \pi}{7}}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{9 \pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{7}} \cos \frac{9 \pi}{7} = 0 $$
So $S = \frac{1}{4} (0) + \frac{3}{4} (0) = 0$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$

inference:
Let $x = \frac{2 \pi}{7}$.
The sum is
$$ S = \cos^3 x + \cos^3 2x + \cos^3 4x = \frac{\cos 3x + 3 \cos x}{4} + \frac{\cos 6x + 3 \cos 2x}{4} + \frac{\cos 12x + 3 \cos 4x}{4} = \frac{1}{4} (\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x) + \frac{3}{4} (\cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x). $$
Using the sum-to-product formula,
\begin{align*} \cos x + \cos 2x + \cos 4x &= \frac{\sin \frac{7x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} \cos \frac{3x}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{7(2\pi/7)}{2}}{\sin \frac{2\pi/7}{2}} \cos \frac{3(2\pi/7)}{2} \\ &= \frac{\sin \pi}{\sin \frac{\pi}{7}} \cos \frac{3\pi}{7} = 0 \end{align*} 
and
\begin{align*} \cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x &= \frac{\sin \frac{9x}{2}}{\sin \frac{3x}{2}} \cos \frac{9x}{2} = \frac{\sin \frac{9(2\pi/7)}{2}}{\sin \frac{3(2\pi/7)}{2}} \cos \frac{9(2\pi/7)}{2} \\ &= \frac{\sin \frac{9\pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{3\pi}{7}} \cos \frac{9\pi}{7} = \frac{-\sin \frac{9\pi}{7}}{ \sin \frac{3\pi}{7}} (-\cos \frac{9\pi}{7}) = \frac{\sin \frac{2\pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{3\pi}{7}} (-\cos \frac{2\pi}{7}) \ne 0 \end{align*} 
Since $\sin \frac{2\pi}{7} \neq 0$, $\sin \frac{3\pi}{7} \neq 0$, $\cos \frac{9\pi}{7} \neq \pm 1$.
Thus $\cos 3x + \cos 6x + \cos 12x = \frac{\sin \frac{9 \pi}{7}}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{7}} \cos \frac{9 \pi}{7} = \frac{\sin (2\pi/7)}{\sin(3\pi/7)} \cos(2\pi/7)$.

$$ S = \frac{1}{4} \cdot 0 + \frac{3}{4} \cdot 0 = 0 $$
Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$
ground_truth:
The triple angle formula states that $\cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta.$  Then
\[\cos^3 \theta = \frac{1}{4} \cos 3 \theta + \frac{3}{4} \cos \theta.\]Hence,
\begin{align*}
\cos^3 \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos^3 \frac{8 \pi}{7} &= \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} \right) + \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \right) + \left( \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{24 \pi}{7} + \frac{3}{4} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \left( \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{24 \pi}{7} \right) + \frac{3}{4} \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \left( \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \right) + \frac{3}{4} \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} \right) \\
&= \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7}.
\end{align*}Consider the sum
\[S = \operatorname{cis} 0 + \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7}.\]Then
\begin{align*}
S \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} &= \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} 2 \pi \\
&= \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \dots + \operatorname{cis} \frac{12 \pi}{7} + \operatorname{cis} 0 \\
&= S,
\end{align*}so $S \left( 1 - \operatorname{cis} \frac{2 \pi}{7} \right) = 0.$  Hence, $S = 0.$

Taking the real part of $S$ gives us
\[\cos 0 + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{10 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{12 \pi}{7} = 0.\]Then
\[1 + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} = 0,\]so
\[\cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} + \cos \frac{6 \pi}{7} = \boxed{-\frac{1}{2}}.\]
